title: Hurricane Dorian’s Path Churns Northward Toward Carolinas
text:
CHARLESTON, S.C.—Hurricane Dorian churned toward the Carolinas on Wednesday evening, threatening large-scale flooding and powerful winds after demolishing parts of the Bahamas and sparing Florida.

The Category 2 hurricane, which strengthened slightly with winds of 110 miles an hour, was located 150 miles south of Charleston and moving at 8 miles an hour, the National Hurricane Center said. Hurricane-force winds extended 70 miles out from the storm center.

Forecasters warned the storm would approach the coast of South Carolina Wednesday night, move near or over the coast of South Carolina on Thursday and then near or over North Carolina’s coast on Thursday night and Friday. Surging waters could cause severe flooding in some areas, but the storm isn’t expected to intensify, they said.

North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said the state has experienced deadly hurricanes in the past, but he warned that complacency could be deadly. “Please don’t let familiarity get in the way of good judgment,” he said.

Mr. Cooper said Dorian continued to be a very dangerous storm, with the possibility of dumping heavy rain along the coast for well over 24 hours starting Thursday morning. Forecasters expect storm surge could raise water levels on the North Carolina coast by as much as 4 to 7 feet above normal tide.

Schools in North Carolina were canceled ahead of the storm as far inland as Raleigh, more than two hours’ drive from the coast. In Wilmington, downtown businesses had placed sandbags by their doors and windows in expectation that the Cape Fear River would flood downtown streets, as it did during Hurricane Florence last year.

Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam also has declared an emergency in anticipation of the storm striking his state’s coast. The hurricane center on Wednesday issued tropical-storm and storm-surge warnings for the parts of the state.

Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp told a news conference in Atlanta the storm’s slow movement was “unheard of” and prolonged its disruption of people’s lives, as governments worked to coordinate emergency responses, issue evacuation orders and manage roadways to and from the coast.

“I know that’s frustrating for our people,” he said. “They’ve been through way too much of this. But we’ve got to hunker down and chop some wood and get through one more.”

Florida was spared the brunt of the storm, leaving residents breathing a sigh of relief. By Wednesday afternoon, traffic returned to streets, and supermarkets, shops and other businesses began reopening in the central, coastal part of the state.

In Volusia County, home to Daytona Beach, fire crews inspected structures and found no major damage, and power outages were minimal, said George Recktenwald, the county manager.

“To say we dodged a bullet for the storm would be an understatement,” he said. “Obviously we dodged a missile.”

President Trump, who approved emergency declarations in Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas, expressed relief Wednesday that the storm didn’t batter Florida as feared. He cautioned that the Carolinas and other states were still threatened.

Appearing before reporters Wednesday in the Oval Office, the president held up a previously published hurricane projection showing a path through Florida. It contained a black line extending the path into Alabama. Mr. Trump had tweeted over the weekend that Alabama could be among the states in the path, which forecasters said wasn’t true.

At an event later in the day, Mr. Trump said, “I know Alabama was in the original forecast.” Asked about the black line on the map, he said, “I don’t know. I don’t know. I don’t know.”

The White House didn’t respond to a request for comment.

The governors of Georgia and South Carolina issued mandatory evacuation orders for coastal counties. Mr. Cooper ordered a mandatory evacuation of all of North Carolina’s barrier islands.

Across Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, the American Red Cross had 170 shelters open that served 13,000 people, said Charley English, the group’s emergency management liaison. With additional shelters opening in North Carolina, the group said it could temporarily house as many as 60,000 people. In Georgia, state shelters were housing 5,600 people and could handle more, according to officials. Animal shelters were housing dogs, cats and about 300 horses, officials said.

In the northern Bahamas, the U.S. Coast Guard continued search-and-rescue operations with support from Customs and Border Protection, according to the U.S. Embassy in Nassau. As of late Tuesday, rescuers had successfully airlifted 61 people from affected areas, it said.

The death toll from Dorian rose to seven, Bahamas Prime Minister Hubert Minnis said Tuesday evening. “We can expect more deaths,” he said. “Let us as a people have compassion for the families of those who lost their lives.”

Debris and destruction on the island Great Abaco in the northern Bahamas, photographed Tuesday during a government reconnaissance mission. Photo: paul halliwell/u.k. ministry of defense/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

The National Emergency Management Agency of the Bahamas issued an all-clear notice Wednesday morning for Grand Bahama, Abaco, Bimini and the Berry Islands as the storm left. But the agency cautioned people to be careful of downed power lines, severe flooding, fallen trees and other debris.

Workers place boards over a business on King Street ahead of the arrival of Hurricane Dorian in Charleston, S.C., on Tuesday. Photo: randall hill/Reuters

—Valerie Bauerlein and Alex Leary contributed to this article.
